review.title: Maximum entropy models for generation of expressive music
review.abstract: In the context of contemporary monophonic music, expression can be seen as the difference between a musical performance and its symbolic representation, i.e. a musical score. In this paper, we show how Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt) models can be used to generate musical expression in order to mimic a human performance. As a training corpus, we had a professional pianist play about 150 melodies of jazz, pop, and latin jazz. The results show a good predictive power, validating the choice of our model. Additionally, we set up a listening test whose results reveal that on average, people significantly prefer the melodies generated by the MaxEnt model than the ones without any expression, or with fully random expression. Furthermore, in some cases, MaxEnt melodies are almost as popular as the human performed ones.

sections.heading: 3 Conclusion & perspectives
sections.text: The structure of this model (see Figure 2), despite the pairing nature of the information used, leads to the replication of complex patterns. The pairing correlations also deal with both continuous and categorical variables. The results are particularly satisfying for a stereotypical style such as swing, while encouraging more complex styles such as ballads or Latin jazz. One of the most challenging perspectives is to allow an expression model to add or remove notes. This model would be very useful if it were also taken into account in terms of the complexity of music.
